creator: Silvio.Wanka@tietoenator.com
text:
vhost def:

<VirtualHost *:80>
    ServerName my-alias
    ServerPath /my-alias
    DocumentRoot /home/www/my-alias

    Alias /test /opt/my-alias/test

    <Directory /opt/my-alias/test>
        ...
    </Directory>
</VirtualHost>

If I use a HTTP/1.1 browser all works ok, but if I
try e.g.

%telnet <server> <port>
GET /my-alias/test HTTP/1.0

I get: 404 Not Found

Workaround:

1. remove Alias definition
2. change
    <Directory /opt/my-alias/test>
   to
    <Directory /home/www/my-alias/test>
3. ln -s /opt/my-alias/test /home/www/my-alias/test

now it works. Please change the vhost-docu (uasage of aliases and
ServerPath not possible) or fix the bug.

Virtual hosts require the HTTP Host header, which is supplied by both HTTP/1.0 
and 1.1 browsers and other real-life agents.  Nothing that is based on a 
virtual host context will work with your one-line request. 
 
That's why we have the Host header, and why HTTP/1.1 made it mandatory after 
real-life browsers were already using it in HTTP/1.0.
creator: nick@webthing.com
Silvio.Wanka@tietoenator.com
text:
Sorry but this is not correct, please look in your documentation and in the
HTTP 1.0 definitions:

at the end of page http://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.0/en/vhosts/name-based.html
you can find:

--- begin copy from apache docu ---

Compatibility with Older Browsers:

As mentioned earlier, there are some clients who do not send the required data 
for the name-based virtual hosts to work properly. These clients will always be 
sent the pages from the first virtual host listed for that IP address (the 
primary name-based virtual host).

How much older?
Please note that when we say older, we really do mean older. You are very 
unlikely to encounter one of these browsers in use today. All current versions 
of any browser send the Host header as required for name-based virtual hosts.

There is a possible workaround with the ServerPath directive, albeit a slightly 
cumbersome one:

--- end copy from apache docu ---

[....please read the original...]

So if you mean this feature is not necessary any more, then remove it from the
documentation and the allowed httpd.conf key words. Otherwise please fix it.

Your request for /my-alias/test never touches the Alias /test directive.  If you
want it to work, simply add
Alias /my-alias/test /opt/my-alias/test

And yes, you are wasting your time, because no browser old or broken enough to
need the ServerPath directive will be of any use on the modern web.  It can't be
easily removed from apache for backward-compatibility reasons, but I think the
docs warn you pretty explicitly that there is no need for this.
creator: slive@apache.org
